Rabies infections increase in northeastern Thailand

Dr. Tawichai, a veterinarian at the 9th Disease Prevention and Control Office, said on February 9 that in the past few months, rabies infections have been on the rise in northeastern Thailand, with a total of 74 cases.

So far this year (from October last year to September this year), 74 people have been diagnosed with rabies through testing, 67 of whom were in Surin province and 7 in Buri Ram province in the northeast.
They said that everyone had received the rabies vaccine in the past.
The doctor is urging people to get vaccinated against rabies along with their pets, and to avoid touching the saliva of animals suspected of being infected.
Rabies is not only transmitted by dogs, but also by cats and bats.
Almost 100% of people who get infected and develop symptoms will die, but vaccination before symptoms can prevent death.

Fujitsu: Experimenting with a system to prevent accidents caused by leaving things behind | The Mid-Japan Economist: Economic Information from Aichi, Gifu, Mie, and Shizuoka

FUJI (head office: Chiryu city) is engaged in the production and sales of electronic components and robots, and has started developing a system to prevent "leaving behind children in the car" and other "forgetting" incidents in cars.
A sensor detects movement inside the vehicle, and sends a notification via phone or chat.
Currently, they are conducting a trial run using their own vehicles.
In the midst of incidents where children are left behind and suffer, the company is working to ensure the safety of children.
Two vehicles are currently being used for the trial in the after-school English conversation school for children "teracoya THANK (TeraCoya Thank)" operated by the company in Chiryu City.
Three motion sensors, which detect movement by the difference in temperature between a person and their surroundings, have been installed on the ceiling of the car.
When the vehicle engine is turned off and the door is closed, and a certain time has passed, if it detects human movement, it will automatically send a warning notification.
By linking the engine and door status with information, it is possible to prevent false alarms as much as possible.
The warning is sent via the cloud.
The number is also displayed on the computer or smartphone chat.
It can register multiple addresses, and it is designed to prevent mistakes such as missing the person.
The trial will continue until the end of February.
Chief Kamaya Ichikou of the Innovation Promotion Department 2nd Section pointed out, "During the experiment, we were able to see surrounding issues that were not related to the system."
For example, it was able to identify various issues related to the school bus, such as the driver's environment that allows them to concentrate on driving.
"If we can expand the scope of the solution, we will do our best."
The reason for the development of a system to prevent leaving things behind was an accident in which a bus that was following another bus nationwide left something behind.
There was a proposal from an employee who has a young child, asking what could be done to ensure the safety of children.
They decided to develop it by utilizing the know-how of IoT and information management using sensors that they have cultivated through their factory automation business.
FUJI's parking prevention system is popular because it is easy to use.
The sensors can be installed just by sticking them to the ceiling with a pin.
Since it can be easily attached to a vehicle used to pick up passengers, we aim to lower the hurdle for adoption and promote it widely.
In the future, they will consider productization in cooperation with daycare centers and kindergartens.

As a city, it is considering land use and renovation concepts based on the location of the new station, and has allocated 3 million yen in this year's budget as a business to formulate a basic plan, but it is expected to remain unimplemented.
The city planning centered on the new station will take time as "it will take time to reach consensus among citizens" (City representative).
There is an example of a suburban new station not co-located with an existing JR station, such as Echizen City, but it will take a considerable amount of time to summarize the overall concept.
The longer it takes to announce the location, the shorter the preparation period for the opening, and there is concern that this will affect the surrounding area.
There is a sense of ambiguity about the extension of the line to the west of Dazaifu, before the new station is built.

In October last year, a citizens' group in Kyoto City, which is along the extension route, submitted a petition to the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, demanding the withdrawal of the extension plan.

In Ishikawa Prefecture, voices calling for a reconsideration of the Miyahara route have been growing, and there have been movements to revert to the route setting that has already been decided, making it difficult for neighboring prefectures to take a firm stance.

The reaction of the citizens of Kohama City to the delay in construction is relatively calm, but there is concern that the impact on future morale will continue as the location and opening date of the new station remain unclear.

Mayor Matsuzaki Kōji will continue to appeal to the government for an early opening of the entire line, but the voices of the regions along the line that demand early construction will be indispensable.
The attitude of "it will eventually be connected to the Shinkansen, so it doesn't matter" cannot move the national, neighboring prefecture, and local governments.
We need to keep raising our voices.
Chocolate sales area for Valentine's Day = Seibu Fukui, Fukui, Fukui Prefecture, February 9th, 2023. The trial sales have been revived after three years.

With Valentine's Day on February 14th approaching, chocolate prices have been rising due to the increase in the price of raw materials and packaging materials, but sales of "gourmet chocolate" for personal use and chocolate for families and friends in the high price range are doing well.
In convenience stores and confectionery stores in Fukui Prefecture, products are being promoted with a focus on local color, luxury, and the use of high-quality materials to attract customers.
Seibu Fukui (Fukui City) opened a special sales area on the 6th floor of the event space on January 25th.
As of the 14th, they have sold approximately 450 varieties of chocolate, including 10 confectionery stores in the prefecture.
Popular items include sand-themed products made with Fukui sake, such as chocolate and cookies with pave chocolate, and other items.
According to the store staff, the prices of the products have risen by about 10% compared to last year.

This year, there are many products that stand out by focusing on the ingredients and packaging to give a high-end feel. The trend among consumers is to buy them for themselves and their families, and to enjoy comparing them.
Despite the trend of price increases, sales of high-priced items are doing well.
⇒Average price per piece is 25 yen due to the high price of goods.
The staff said, "We are focusing on creating a sales floor where you can enjoy the Valentine's Day event itself."
At the store, they have been selling recommended sweets on a rotating basis since January 26th, and have also restarted free samples after a three-year hiatus.

Western confectionery and sales shop Kurafubu (head office: Sakai-shi Maruoka-cho 1-chome Ichida-cho) has for the first time introduced its original chocolate "Kiseki (Kiseki)" series, which was jointly developed with a long-established French chocolate maker at the end of last year, into the Valentine's Day battle.
The chocolate is characterized by its fruity taste that is not bitter, and is sold in packs of three for 1,000 yen and nine for 3,000 yen.

Takahara Ryuma, the president of the purchasing department of the parent company, said, "The culture of giving giri choco is thinning out, but there is a need for a little bit of fun on Valentine's Day. We will increase the value of the product and differentiate it."
⇒ 女性にチョコレートを贈るには...話題のAIチャットボットに質問

A 20-something female office worker from Fukui city who visited the Seibu Fukui store on the 9th said, "I like chocolate, and I want to buy it as a treat for myself because I can earn money now that I'm working."

A 30-year-old female employee (same company) who bought giri choco said, "It's painful that the price increase has reached chocolate, but I want to give it to my family or someone I often deal with once a year. However, I might give it to fewer people."
Products using Fukui Ume and Fukui-produced Midi Tomatoes = February 9, Fukui Prefectural Government
Seven-Eleven Japan will sell six new products, including items made with sweet Fukui-grown ingredients, at 339 stores in three prefectures in Hokkaido from February 9.
As a commemorative event for the first anniversary of the comprehensive cooperation agreement covering all aspects of prefectural government, it appeals to the charm of prefecture-made products.

Scheduled to be sold until the 20th.

Governor Sugimoto tasted the fish ball soup and said, "The sweet shrimp is really well-represented and it's delicious." giving it a thumbs up.
The company representative said, "We will continue to expand products using Fukui-made ingredients in the future."
The ruins of Ushikohara Castle, which was built to prepare for the battle with Hiraizumi Temple = Fukui Prefecture Ono City Ushikohara
It was once a large manor estate in the dry side of Ikawa-cho, Ono City, Fukui Prefecture.

The castle of Ukegohara, which was built in the stomach of the mountain of Tokoyama in preparation for the battle against Hiraizumi Temple, which was in opposition to the manor estate during the Kamakura period.
It is mentioned in the military chronicle "Taiheiki".
There is no information about the Niigakehara Castle, but in the "Echizen Niigakehara Castle Self-harm Incident" in the eleventh volume of the Taiheiki, it is written as follows.
Aikawa Ukyo no Suke (Takahiro) was sent to Ono as a magistrate, as he was a Kamakura shogunate official.

In 1333, the Rokuhara Tandai, which was established in Kyoto to monitor the imperial court and control the western region, was defeated by Ashikaga Takauji, and the Kamakura shogunate was destroyed by Nitta Yoshisada.
When they heard the news that the Rokuhara Tandai had been killed, the family of the lord of the house, including the lord himself, all escaped in a hurry, leaving only about 20 people behind.
They took advantage of the gap and attacked the monks of Hiraizumi.
Sukehito, his wife and two children drowned themselves in the river, and then he followed them.
⇒ Nobunaga, Hideyoshi, and Ieyasu gathered to defend the city that would not fall.
The "Association for Improving the Dry Side" made up of local residents published "A History of the Dry Side" in 2014.
The story of the tragic fate of Jikyo is explained in a comic book that is easy for elementary school students to understand.

Participating in the publication was Kitagawa Seiichi (75), who said, "I hope that the people of the region will learn about a history that is familiar to them, and that it will be passed down to future generations."
⇒ Enjoying the castles in Fukui Prefecture "Fukui Castle Tour"
Ushikahara Castle
The castle ruins have a trail maintained by the "Let's Improve the Dry Side" group.
It is about 200 meters from the entrance to the mountain.
The road leading to the mountain entrance is closed to cars in winter due to heavy snow.
The Society for the Maintenance of the Dry Side
Approximately 220 households in the dry side of the city of Ono have joined.
In the past, they have published "Kan's Triplets," a guidebook introducing ancient tombs, historical sites, and scenic spots in the region.
The roadside station "Rennyo no Sato Awara" in Yoshizaki, Awara City, Fukui Prefecture, which is undergoing renovations, will open on April 22nd.

With the opening of Awara Onsen Station on the Hokuriku Shinkansen in spring 2024, the city plans to develop the area north of the city as a new regional revitalization and tourist attraction, with an estimated 360,000 users per year.
The main food and retail facility at the station will be a one-storey steel frame construction with a total floor space of 975m².
The total area of the station, including the parking lot and the tideland children's park, is 8,137 square meters.
The facility will also have a rest area and a tourist information center.
Electric bicycles can be rented, and there is a shower room.
The two parking lots can accommodate 66 cars (including 3 for the disabled).
Mayor Morimoto of the city made this clear at the regular meeting on February 8.
In the food corner, fruits from the Sakai North Hill are used to sell parfaits and pies for the golden hour.
They are developing a menu that uses local products to the fullest, such as a rice bowl with eggs made from Fukuchiyama chicken, and autumn and winter limited dishes made with eel from Hokkaido.
Currently, about 60 businesses are members of the "Shipper Council" at the direct sales store.
They will also stock processed food such as bento and set meals, as well as agricultural and horticultural products such as saplings and trees.

In the souvenir corner, works by artists who have exhibited at the Mori Art Museum, which is run by the Kintetsu Creative Corporation, will be displayed and sold, as well as sweets, alcohol, and traditional crafts.
⇒ Roadside Station Ranking, Kinki's "Nansei-sanri-kairi" is number one

The designated management and operation company that manages and operates the station is Awara Ninki Goukoukai (Awara-shi, Yoshikawa 2-chome), which was founded by Miyake Masao, the president of Miyake Shoten, which operates the rabbit-touching theme park "Tsukimi Usagi no Sato" in Kaga City, Ishikawa Prefecture.
In the interview, Mayor Mori said, "We will revitalize Awara city as a whole, promote it, and contribute to the improvement of the lives of local residents and the activation of the region."
The cat-shaped feeding robot has been introduced at the "Jingisukan (grilled mutton) aging at Ishigaki Salt" store in front of Fukui Station.
Fukui City, Fukui Prefecture: Popular with families thanks to friendly expressions and the like = Fukui City, Fukui Prefecture, Ote 2-chome
In the food and beverage industry in Fukui Prefecture, which is suffering from a shortage of labor, the number of restaurants introducing delivery robots that bring food to the table is increasing.

The robots are helpful for reducing the need for staff in store operations and for contactless customer service to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus, and their cute expressions are popular with families.
The voices of restaurant owners and their associates saying, "It is difficult for local restaurants to secure employees and part-time workers, so the delivery robot will spread even more," are heard.
"Jin, Jin, Jin-gi-su-kan ♪".
A robot, which plays light music and displays a cat's face on the screen, moves smoothly around the store while carrying the dishes.
When it arrives at the table in the dining room, it says, "I've brought your order, nyaa."
The "Ishiruka Jinkusanbon Fukui Station Store" in Fukui, which is located in the 2-chome of Fukui's Omiya, introduced a cat-shaped food delivery robot in August 2022.
The robot waits near the kitchen and, when a customer orders something on the screen, it will autonomously navigate to the table and deliver the food.
AI(artificial intelligence) voice function and other features are built in, and the robot responds when touched by the customer, and the cat face on the screen also has a rich range of expressions.
The "Bonta Group" that operates this store has introduced two feeding robots in the store, including this store.

President Saito Satoshi said that the reason for introducing the robot was "lack of manpower", and emphasized that it was a part of efforts to reduce labor costs and increase productivity through digital transformation (DX).
The proportion of labor costs to sales revenue is usually around 30%, but it has been reduced to 21% to 22% by introducing the robot.

The robot also collects plates after customers finish eating, which is related to the efficiency of cleaning up, and adds that "families with children are happy, and it also has a promotional effect."
The "Rokkan Hoshimaya Fukui Store" in Araki Shinpo-cho, Fukui City, which serves grilled meat and hot pot, introduced a food delivery robot in August 2022.

The president of Hoshizaki Eifuku, which operates a Sonan supermarket, said, "I couldn't find employees or part-timers no matter how much I recruited. I thought it was absolutely necessary to solve the labor shortage."
The Fukui store separates the zone where employees serve food from the zone where robots deliver food.
The cost of leasing a robot is about the same as the salary of one worker.
In order to reduce the number of staff, the store has also introduced a tablet-based ordering system, and is considering introducing self-service.

According to the Fukui Labor Bureau, the effective recruitment ratio for the "customer service" category in the food and beverage industry was 6.94 times in December 2022, and there is a high shortage of labor.

The person in charge of the delivery robot sales agency system (located at Takagi Chuo 2-chome, Fukui) said, "The labor shortage in Fukui's restaurants has become more serious due to the impact of the coronavirus, and there are many inquiries about introducing delivery robots."
President Hoshizaki said, "I think that it will be even more difficult for local suburban stores to secure employees in the future, and I think that delivery robots will become more widespread."
[Opinion] Echizen Town has created a "Death of a Salesman" and is distributing it to the citizens it hopes to attract.

They published a "handbook for the deceased" last year, which covers all the procedures and writing styles needed when someone dies, as well as a family tree, and they had a lot of people coming to pick up copies for themselves.

In each district of the prefecture, seminars on how to write an obituary and how to prepare for one's death are being held, and it seems that the concept of "end of life" has become firmly established among the citizens.
Echizen's Ending Note is 35 pages.

The fifth chapter starts with a summary of one's own history, and goes on to write about one's current health and assets, future care, hopes for end-of-life medical care, and wishes regarding funeral and grave.
There is also a section for things you want to do before you die and messages to loved ones.
It looks like it would be easy to break if you wrote on all 35 pages, but you don't have to fill up all the pages.
What do you want to leave behind for your family and the people around you?
The most important thing is to make your wishes clear.
There are many different coloured and patterned notebooks available in shops, and you can start writing in them from anywhere.
The term "end of life" was born in 2009, when I started working.
The Great East Japan Earthquake occurred in 2011, two years later.
It is said that many people have come to realize the reality that "death comes suddenly," and that more people are preparing for their final days and end of life.
That was 10 years ago.
The new coronavirus pandemic that swept the world is still not under control.
The prices have risen due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and the electricity bill this winter has jumped to an unbelievable price.
On the other hand, wages have not risen in line with the current high prices, and many people are struggling to keep up.
On the other hand, funeral expenses, care fees and grave maintenance, which used to be shared with the family and neighbors, are now the responsibility of the only child.
Another dilemma is that although life expectancy has increased significantly compared to a few decades ago, the risk of dementia and needing care increases as you get older.
It is important to remember that in the background of a transient life, there is also a growing sense of social anxiety.
Whatever, everyone would want to avoid putting an undue burden on their partner or children.
"Dying with dignity" is a popular phrase from Death with Dignity, but it can't be taken too far.
I don't want to write down my hopes and wishes in secret, but rather talk to my family once about it and prepare calmly.
Prime Minister Kishida (right, second from left) and Education Minister Nagaoka Keiko (same photo, third from left) with related personnel in a primary school, in a commemorative photo.
On the 10th of February, in Toda City, Saitama Prefecture, the graduation ceremony showed that it was not necessary for children and students, as well as teachers, to wear masks.
The Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided on February 10 that students at graduation ceremonies should not wear masks, and that it is the norm not to wear them.

The principal of a large junior high school said, "It's difficult to keep a wide distance between students, and I'm worried about how to respond. There are also students who feel uneasy about taking off their masks."
The issue has also been raised among teachers after hearing reports of students wearing masks at graduation ceremonies.

On the other hand, the principal of one elementary school said, "If the government says not to wear masks, then it will be difficult to respond practically, excluding singing," and took a cautious stance.

In this graduation ceremony, some schools have allowed students who were self-isolating to attend, and have restarted the graduation song sung by graduating students, and some schools in the prefecture are trying to ease the countermeasures.
In the prefecture, prefectural high schools are planning to hold graduation ceremonies in early March, and public junior high schools in mid-March.

The prefectural board of education and city/town boards of education are waiting for an official notice from the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology before deciding on their response.
In addition, there are voices of caution regarding the Ministry of Education's decision to not require masks to be worn in school education activities from the new term this spring.

The principal of an elementary school said, "Children will be confused if we suddenly stop wearing masks. It's natural that the number of children who don't wear masks will increase if we first decide that 'wearing masks is optional,' and then gradually ease the rules."

The Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided on February 10 that from April, it will not require masks to be worn in school education activities, following the government's new guidelines.
Masks will not be required in singing, physical education classes, or club activities.

In the middle of 2022, it will seek to implement infection countermeasures in line with the current health management manual, and will disseminate the guidelines for April and onwards to the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology and schools.

Graduation ceremonies for elementary, junior high, high schools, and universities will also be held without masks in the 2022 academic year, as long as ventilation and other measures are taken. Graduates, teachers, and students attending the ceremony will not be required to wear masks.
Eita Kan (left), who cuts the hair of students who have passed the exam, at the hair salon Limuru in Tsucho-cho, Echizen-shi, Fukui Prefecture

At the hair salon "Limuru" in Tsucho-cho, Echizen City, Fukui Prefecture, they cut the hair of the students who are taking the entrance exams every year, using scissors that have been used to cut the hair of students who have passed the exams.
The applicants said, "I gained confidence," and "I was able to take the exam calmly."

Nagata Kou, the representative director of the same beauty salon, has seen students open their textbooks while waiting for their turn to get their hair cut, or express their anxiety about the exams while getting their hair cut.
From there, he started the "hope cut" in 2014, with the idea that "even a little bit can be helpful."

In the same beauty salon, every year, on the day of starting work, they go to the head office of Wakatake Town, Fukui, and ask for a prayer for passing the scissors and comb exams.
About 80 people receive a haircut every year.
It includes entrance examinations for high schools and universities, employment examinations, and driver's license examinations.
They present the pencil that was used to write the passing grade.

In 2021, a man (19) who received a haircut and successfully entered Tokyo University as an active member, said, "I was encouraged by the feeling of being supported. I used the gold pencil I received to take the exam, and I was motivated."
NPO Law Person "Kokoro-Naru Kokuhou-Hanashi-Juku" self-published book "Dear Prime Minister, 'Life's Breakwater' from Toshinbo"
The title of the 10th book, "Dear Prime Minister of the Imperial Cabinet, 'Life's Breakwater' from Tōjinbō", was self-published.
It has been reported by newspapers across the country, and many readers have sent in their thoughts.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share the "social and structural" environmental issues that are the cause of suicide in Japan, as told directly by those who have attempted suicide, and to create a "society with a good heart" together.

We have been patrolling the water's edge of Tōjinbō in Fukui Prefecture, which is known as a suicide spot, for 18 months and 10 days to prevent suicide, and we have been supporting the activities of those who have attempted suicide.

This book is a summary of the issues heard from the 784 people (2/6 currently) that we have protected, and we are advocating the following 7 points to the Prime Minister as measures necessary to prevent suicide.
(1) Suicide prevention activities are "life-saving" activities.
(2)Behind suicide, there is a mountain of "human rights violation".
(3) Suicide victims are victims of organized crime that is socially and structurally organized.
(4)Administrative agencies treat citizens who live outside their jurisdiction as "others" and are cold to them.
(5) Mental disorders such as depression are treated with drugs, and suicide is treated as an "accident".
(6)The "duty of care" for safety in high risk areas for suicide is being forgotten and commercialism is being pursued.
(7)New religions teach doctrines that cannot be scientifically proven, and they threaten and extort money from people by telling them that they will be cursed in the future.
It is necessary to publicly denounce and exclude the religious organization that commits the crime of "fraud and intimidation".

In that regard, I would like to introduce a part of the comments we received from readers who purchased this book, such as "I was moved by the strong mental fortitude of those who are involved in this activity," "I was impressed by the former police officer's attitude," and "I am amazed that even though they are strangers, they support each other like family members."
I was moved to tears when I saw the photo in the newspaper article and thought, "What must they be feeling..."
I hear that suicide is increasing among people who are being pushed into a corner due to the corona disaster.
It is really sad.
They are all human beings.
I hope that we can live in a society where we can live happily with our own lives.
I felt respect and gratitude for the staff who are giving their all to those who are suffering as much as they would if they were dying.
I think this activity is very hard on both the body and mind, so I hope that you will continue to take care of yourself and speak out.
Thank you.
Kashiko
I hope that you, the readers, will become gatekeepers of life in your region.

This is a column by the NPO corporation "Kokoro-Nakimaru-Bungakubu" (represented by Yukio Shige), which is based in Fukui Prefecture and is dedicated to helping people who are considering suicide at Tōjinbō.
Shikata Kenji, who takes pictures of capybaras every week and posts them on SNS, = On February 1, the indoor facility "Happyjan" in Fukui City's Asuwa Park Amusement Park in Fukui Prefecture.
There is a man in Fukui City who takes pictures of the beavers in the indoor facility "Hapishyan" of Fukui City Asuwa Park Amusement Park every week and posts them on Instagram.
The thumbnail images of the posts include a wide-open mouth yawning, a man lying down and stretching out his arms, and other diverse images.
With over 10,000 followers both in Japan and abroad, he uses the account to spread the charm of Hapishan and Capybara to many people.
⇒ Ms. Kudou Shizuka posts Fukui Prefecture's traditional vegetables on Instagram
The man is Shimada Kenji (38), who lives in the city and works for a company.
He began posting on the exchange site (SNS) in March 2021.
The capybara is the largest rodent in the world and is a good swimmer, with webbed feet.
Hapisyan has been breeding three capybaras, one male and two females, since it opened 18 years ago, and can observe them closely and feed them.
Mr Shimada discovered the capybara five or six years ago.
He was shocked to see a video of the animal relaxing in a hot spring and wondered, "What kind of animal is this?"
I was drawn to their human-like expressions and demeanor.
After that, I was looking forward to being able to see them up close and personal when they were kept at Hapijyan.
He started taking photos seriously about 3 years ago, when he bought a single-lens reflex camera.

He uses his camera to capture the cute appearance of the capybara, and he doesn't miss any chance to take a picture of them, such as when they shake their bodies like a bulldog and cut the water like a drill.
He has posted about 830 photos on Instagram, and he says, "I'm glad I took this many photos."
It seems that the male Yamato has come close to Shimada-san, who he remembers from passing by, and is going to make a "kyurukyuru" sound.
At the same time, Shimada's love for capybaras deepens with the thought that they are cute and fun.
I enjoy exchanging messages with capybara lovers all over the country through SNS and showing them my best shots every month.
Smiling, Shikada said, "I'll be visiting zoos in nearby prefectures to see the capybaras, and I'll be taking and sharing more photos of them, focusing on my home, Mount Asuwa."
She searches for "kapihopon" on Instagram.
Toba City to double child-rearing household allowance payments, but some want refunds - Ise Newspaper

[Toba] Toba City announced on the 10th that a total of 600,000 yen was mistakenly paid to 12 people in 11 households in the special subsidy for child-rearing households (other household division) in fiscal 2020.
The city is currently apologizing to the recipients and explaining the circumstances, while also asking for the money to be returned.
According to the city, the error was discovered on January 27, 2020, when the guardians of the children who had received the payments in the past came to confirm the past payments.
It was confirmed that 182 people in 11 households received double payment of the subsidy on July 20, 2020, among the 182 households who received subsidies in the same year.
The city pays 50,000 yen per child to households exempt from residential taxation with children under high school age.

The city received data from the outsourced accounting company that extracted the target children, but the employee in charge mistakenly added the data to the list, thinking it did not include high school students, and thus the payment was made twice.
The staff of the city's child-rearing support room said, "We will take strict measures, check the data again, and make every effort to prevent recurrence and restore trust."

On the 10th, Iwate Prefecture and Ichinoseki City announced that they would provide subsidies to hotels that would reduce the accommodation fees of tourists, and announced that the Belino Hotel Ichinoseki (Ichinoseki, Yamanaka) had been inappropriately used from October 2021 to about one year.
When people who were not eligible for the discount stayed, they applied the discount by having employees lend their names.
It was also confirmed that many of the hotel's employees were using the hotel for their own stays, which did not meet the objective of "stimulating demand for tourism."

The total amount of 7,231,000 yen that was received inappropriately, including the results of the self-inspection by the hotel, has been returned by the prefecture and the city by the 6th of this month.

The illegal receipt of subsidies occurred in the prefecture's "Iwate Travel Support Project" and the city's "Ichinoseki Lodging Support Emergency Measures Project," which were implemented in response to the spread of the new coronavirus.

The period was from October 18, 2021 to October 10, 2022 (Ichinoseki Kokumin Hotel from September 30, 2022), and the investigation found that there were 95 cases of inappropriate use of discounts for people outside the target region or unvaccinated, totaling 58,700 yen, and 1,239 cases of use

The prefecture's contractor was in the process of settling accounts when it was confirmed that the user of the accommodation subsidy and the hotel's reception staff were the same person in multiple cases.

Introducing the pioneers of plant research, and data from Mount Hayachine, at the city's comprehensive cultural property center's exhibition "Hana" | Iwanichi Online | Iwate Nippo Shimbun Co., Ltd.

An exhibition called "People who introduced the flowers of Mount Hayachine, a treasure trove of alpine plants" is being held at the Hanamaki City Cultural Property Center in Hasama Town until the 12th, and introduces the pioneers of the research into the flora of Mount Hayachine, a treasure trove of alpine plants.
The exhibition has collected 124 valuable specimens and data collected by the pioneers, and introduces the footprints of the pioneers who were involved in the plant research of Mount Hayachine.

Hayachine Mountain's botanical research began with the arrival of Russian botanist Karl Johann Maximovitch (1827-91) in the late Edo period, and continued with Sugawa Chonosuke (1842-1925), a native of Shiwa who was guided by Maximovitch in collecting plant specimens.
Maximovich, who was not allowed to walk freely in the country as a foreigner, entrusted the collection to Sugawa and conducted research for three years in Yokohama and Nagasaki as a base.
After Maksimovich's return to Russia, Sukawa continued to support research, and was involved in the announcement of the endemic "Himezakura", "Sanguisorba obtusa", and "Yamabuki-shoumatsu".

After that, modern plant taxonomist Makino Tomitaro (1862-1957) published "Bistorta hayachinensis", "Cobanotusmecki", "Draba japonica" in 1903 (Meiji 36) based on the collection of local researchers, and "Arenaria katoana" in 1905 (Meiji 38) which he discovered and named
From the exhibited materials, it can be seen that many researchers discovered valuable alpine plants.

In addition, the introduction also mentions Shimura Matsuzo (1874-1948), who was a principal of the Hanami Elementary School and conducted botanical research while accompanying the investigation for the preservation of natural monuments in 1927 (Showa 2), and Tamagawa Shichiro (1914-1988), who was a curator at the Hasama Mountain Museum and was involved in

Yoshida Muneo, the researcher of the center, said, "There are many research results and connections between people behind the names of each plant of Mount Hayachine. It is possible to see the connections between researchers who spread from the local area to the whole country."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters. The first chapter focuses on the beliefs and history of Mount Hayachine, and the second chapter looks at the foundations of Japanese geology, which were laid by German geologists such as Edmund Naumann (1854-1927), based on their research on the mountain.

Discussions on renewable energy and goals at the second decarbonization promotion council at Amami Airport | Society and Economy | South China Daily News
Decarbonization promotion council held at Kasari-cho, Amami City on the 9th to discuss decarbonization of Amami Airport

The "Amami Airport Decarbonization Promotion Council" (Chairman: Mr. Anou, Construction Bureau Chief of Oshima Subprefecture, Members: 13 people), which was established to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at Amami Airport (Kasari Town, Amami City), held its second meeting at the airport on the 9th.
All members attended, including those online.
They exchanged opinions on setting targets for decarbonization and introducing renewable energy with solar power generation as the main body.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism is aiming for "carbon neutrality" by 2050, and has set a goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from each airport by 46% or more (compared to 13 years ago) within 30 years.
The council held its first meeting in November last year, and is aiming to lead the way in planning measures for the other six airports in the prefecture.
The second meeting was held in camera, as was the first meeting.

"Sakasama Real Estate" branch office opened on the island to attract people to live there  People are being recruited to live with the family | Society and Economy | South China Daily News
Opening event to deepen understanding of "sakasama-toshiten" = 8th, Chinatown

[Okinoerabu General Affairs Bureau] The opening event for the real estate website service "Sakasama Fudosan" (loosely translated as "empty real estate") which aims to visualize the thoughts of people who want to try renting empty houses or shops, was held on the 8th at the "entaku" community space in China-cho, Naha.
The operating company explained the outline of the service through a talk session.

Representative Director Takino Masahiko (Okubo, Hokkaido Rishiri District) who is in charge of the branch office said, "If we can attract people to the island by implementing this project in Okinoyubu, we can create a flow of people to the island."
Sakasama Fudosan is a service where the person who wants to borrow the property discloses their information to the owner, and if they reach an agreement, they contract with each other.

As a demonstration experiment to discover hidden vacant houses and to establish relationships through vacant houses, Kabushiki Kaisha On-Co (head office in Mie Prefecture) is operating, and started the service in June 2020.
This is the seventh branch to be opened, and the first in Kyushu.
This is the first time in the country, and also the first time in the islands.
About 20 people, including staff from On―Co and Tsukigobo, employees of the town offices of Wadamisaki and the famous towns, and local residents, participated in the event.

Representative Director Okubo explained the background of the branch office opening, saying, "As more and more people from outside the island are being attracted, I thought that if we could make use of vacant houses and shops, the town and the island would grow even more," and described the circumstances leading up to the branch office opening.
"I want to help people who own property on the island or who want to do something, even if it's just one person, to advance their efforts," he said.

Representative Mizutani Takashi of On―Co pointed out that it is necessary to discuss "how to make use of empty houses one by one, what the locals want to do with this region, what kind of people they want to bring in, and what criteria they will use" in the operation.
"The more people are connected, the more information will be gathered," he said, calling for participation in discussions with islanders and cooperation in providing information.
